questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer is designing an OSPF network for a client. Requirements dictate that the routers in Area 1 should receive all routes belonging to the network, including EIGRP, except the ones that originated in the RIP domain. Which action should the engineer take?

choices.D: Make the area 1 routers part of area 0.
choices.C: Make area 1 a standard OSPF area.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
RPF is performed against FHR when in SPT/Source tree state and against RP when in Shared tree state

Selected Answer: D
D is correct. "If a PIM router has no source-tree state, it is considered a shared tree state. The router will perform a RPF check on the address of the rendezvous point â€“ the rendezvous address is known when members join the group"

https://www.routeprotocol.com/reverse-path-forwarding-rpf/
But RPF is not used with PIM-DM? Then it wouldn't be any RP neither shared-trees, but sources one. Would it is so?

Selected Answer: D
D. The PIM router or multilayer switch has a shared-tree state.

In a multicast network, the Reverse Path Forwarding (RPF) check is performed to ensure that multicast traffic flows along the optimal path and to prevent loops. When a PIM router or multilayer switch has a shared-tree state, it means that it is using a shared distribution tree with a Rendezvous Point (RP) at its root. In this case, the RPF check is performed on the RP address to ensure that multicast packets are being received from the correct upstream path toward the RP.

choices.C: The PIM DM device receives a multicast packet and has no directly connected PIM neighbor.
choices.D: The PIM router or multilayer switch has a shared-tree state.
choices.A: The PIM router or multilayer switch has a source-tree state.
choices.B: The PIM DM device receives a multicast packet and has no directly connected members.

questions.question_text: In a multicast network, which condition must be met for an RPF check to be performed on the RP address?
